question: What is a primary purpose of the Controlling a Stage process in PRINCE2?

options.a: To enable the Project Board to be accountable for the project’s success.
options.b: To provide management direction and control throughout the project.
options.c: To monitor the work to be done and deal with issues throughout a stage.
options.d: To ensure that the prerequisites for initiating the project are in place.

reasoning: The purpose of Controlling a Stage is for the Project Manager to monitor the day-to-day work within a stage and manage any issues that arise.

question: Which of the following is a purpose of the Managing Product Delivery process?

options.a: To coordinate an area of work that will deliver one or more of the project’s products.
options.b: To prepare sufficient information to allow the Project Board to authorize the next stage.
options.c: To provide a fixed point in time when the acceptance of the project’s products is confirmed.
options.d: To report to the Project Board on the progress of the stage.

reasoning: Managing Product Delivery coordinates the work of teams to create the specialist products as defined in a Work Package.

question: In which PRINCE2 process does the Project Manager formally delegate responsibility for work or delivery to a Team Manager or team member?

options.a: Initiating a Project.
options.b: Controlling a Stage.
options.c: Managing Product Delivery.
options.d: Managing a Stage Boundary.

reasoning: The Project Manager authorizes a Work Package to delegate work, which is a key activity in the Controlling a Stage process.

question: During which PRINCE2 process are specialist products created?

options.a: Initiating a Project.
options.b: Controlling a Stage.
options.c: Managing Product Delivery.
options.d: Managing a Stage Boundary.

reasoning: The actual hands-on creation of specialist products is done by the teams within the Managing Product Delivery process.

question: Which of the following is typically included in a Work Package?

options.a: Project-level tolerances for cost and time.
options.b: The Project Product Description.
options.c: Problem handling and escalation arrangements.
options.d: A detailed list of all project risks.

reasoning: A Work Package must define the constraints and communication lines for the team, including how to handle problems and escalate issues.

question: What is the primary purpose of a Checkpoint Report?

options.a: To provide a regular update on stage progress to the Project Board.
options.b: To summarize the status of the Work Package to the Project Manager at a defined frequency.
options.c: To document deviations from the plan that require Project Board attention.
options.d: To formally request changes to baselined products.

reasoning: The Checkpoint Report is used by the Team Manager to report the status of a Work Package to the Project Manager.

question: A Checkpoint Report is derived from which of the following? 1. Work Package. 2. Team plan and actuals. 3. Previous Checkpoint Report. 4. Stage Plan.
reasoning: The report is based on the assigned work (Work Package), progress against the plan (team plan and actuals), and may reference the last report for continuity.

question: Who is primarily responsible for creating the Highlight Report, which provides regular progress updates to the Project Board throughout a management stage?

options.a: The Team Manager.
options.b: The Project Manager.
options.c: The Project Board.
options.d: Project Assurance.

reasoning: The Project Manager creates the Highlight Report for the Project Board to keep them informed of stage progress.

question: If a Work Package is forecast to exceed its agreed tolerances, what is the *first* action the Team Manager should take?

options.a: Produce an Exception Report and send it to the Project Manager.
options.b: Inform the Project Manager by raising an issue.
options.c: Cease all work on the Work Package immediately.
options.d: Update the Stage Plan with the new forecast.

reasoning: A forecast deviation against Work Package tolerances is an issue that the Team Manager must immediately raise to the Project Manager.

question: Which of the following management products are regularly maintained by the Project Manager during the Controlling a Stage process? 1. Quality Register. 2. Risk Register. 3. Issue Register. 4. Daily Log.

options.a: 1, 2, and 3 only.
options.b: 1, 2, and 4 only.
options.c: 1, 3, and 4 only.

reasoning: The Project Manager uses all four of these management products to manage the day-to-day activities of the stage.

question: What is the purpose of the 'Review Management Stage Status' activity within the Controlling a Stage process?

options.a: To delegate work packages to Team Managers.
options.b: To obtain approvals for completed products.
options.c: To periodically review the overall situation of the stage and decide what to do next.
options.d: To escalate issues and risks to the Project Board when tolerances are threatened.

reasoning: This activity allows the Project Manager to assess the health of the stage against the plan and decide if any corrective action or escalation is needed.

question: When does a Team Manager typically produce a Team Plan?

options.a: At the beginning of the project, during the Starting Up a Project process.
options.b: When accepting a Work Package from the Project Manager.
options.c: At the end of each management stage, as part of the Managing a Stage Boundary process.
options.d: When the project is forecast to exceed its tolerances, as part of an Exception Plan.

reasoning: A Team Plan, if required, is created by the Team Manager after accepting a Work Package to detail how the work will be executed.

question: Which role is primarily responsible for the 'Execute a Work Package' activity within the Managing Product Delivery process?

options.a: The Project Manager.
options.b: The Team Manager or Team Member.
options.c: Project Assurance.
options.d: The Senior Supplier.

reasoning: The Team Manager or team members are responsible for executing the work defined in the Work Package.

question: The 'Authorize a Work Package' activity is part of which PRINCE2 process?

options.a: Directing a Project.
options.b: Initiating a Project.
options.c: Controlling a Stage.
options.d: Managing a Stage Boundary.

reasoning: Authorizing Work Packages is a key activity for the Project Manager within the Controlling a Stage process.

question: The Controlling a Stage process primarily describes the work of which PRINCE2 role?

options.a: The Project Board.
options.b: The Project Manager.
options.c: The Team Manager.
options.d: The Senior User.

reasoning: Controlling a Stage is the main day-to-day process for the Project Manager.

question: In the Managing Product Delivery process, who is responsible for obtaining approvals for completed products?

options.a: The Project Manager.
options.b: Project Assurance.
options.c: The Team Manager or Team Member.
options.d: The Senior User.

reasoning: The team is responsible for ensuring the products they create meet the quality criteria and getting them approved before delivery.

question: The Project Manager performs the 'Capture and Examine Issues and Risks' activity within the Controlling a Stage process. This activity incorporates which initial steps of the Issue and Change Control Procedure and Risk Management Procedure?

options.a: Issue and Change Control: Capture and Assess; Risk Management: Identify, Assess, and Plan.
options.b: Issue and Change Control: Propose and Decide; Risk Management: Implement and Communicate.
options.c: Issue and Change Control: Implement; Risk Management: Communicate.
options.d: Issue and Change Control: Capture; Risk Management: Identify and Assess.

reasoning: This activity involves the initial steps of capturing and examining issues, and identifying and assessing risks before deciding on further action.

question: During the 'Review Work Package Status' activity of the Controlling a Stage process, what is updated with actuals to date, forecasts, and adjustments?

options.a: The Project Plan.
options.b: The Business Case.
options.c: The Stage Plan.
options.d: The Highlight Report.

reasoning: The Stage Plan is the baseline against which the Project Manager tracks actuals and updates forecasts for the current stage.

question: Which of the following is an objective of the Managing Product Delivery process?

options.a: To ensure that the Team Manager and the teams understand the expected effort, time, and cost needed to deliver the products.
options.b: To ensure that the various ways to deliver the project are evaluated.
options.c: To define how quality management will be carried out during the project.
options.d: To request authorization to start the next stage of the project.

reasoning: This ensures there is a clear and accepted agreement on the work to be done as defined in the Work Package.

question: Which statement best describes the relationship between the Controlling a Stage and Managing Product Delivery processes?

options.a: Controlling a Stage happens before Managing Product Delivery and provides its inputs.
options.b: Managing Product Delivery happens before Controlling a Stage and provides its inputs.
options.c: Controlling a Stage manages the stage, including delegating work, while Managing Product Delivery delivers the specialist products.
options.d: They are independent processes and can occur at any time during the project.

reasoning: There is an interface between the Project Manager (Controlling a Stage) who delegates work, and the Team Manager (Managing Product Delivery) who executes it.
